sn49.1-12:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four right efforts.

sn49.1-12:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.1-12:1.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

sn49.1-12:1.6.pli: Uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.1-12:1.6.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

sn49.1-12:1.7.pli: Anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.1-12:1.7.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

sn49.1-12:1.8.pli: Uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.1-12:1.8.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

sn49.1-12:1.9.eng: These are the four right efforts.

sn49.1-12:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn49.1-12:2.1.eng: The Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn49.1-12:2.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn49.1-12:2.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four right efforts slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn49.1-12:2.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn49.1-12:2.3.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the four right efforts slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn49.1-12:2.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.1-12:2.4.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise.

sn49.1-12:2.5.pli: Uppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.1-12:2.5.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen are given up.

sn49.1-12:2.6.pli: Anuppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ uppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.1-12:2.6.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities arise.

sn49.1-12:2.7.pli: Uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.1-12:2.7.eng: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and strive so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

sn49.1-12:2.8.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cattāro sammappadhāne bhāvento cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn49.1-12:2.8.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the four right efforts slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn49.1-12:4.1.eng: Six on slanting to the east,

sn49.1-12:4.2.eng: and six on slanting to the ocean;

sn49.1-12:4.4.eng: and that’s how this chapter is recited.

sn49.13-22:2.1.eng: The Realized One, footprint, roof peak,

sn49.23-34:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci balakaraṇīyā kammantā kayiranti, sabbe te pathaviṃ nissāya pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhāya evamete balakaraṇīyā kammantā kayiranti;
sn49.23-34:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, all the hard work that gets done depends on the earth and is grounded on the earth.

sn49.23-34:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro sammappadhāne bhāveti, cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaroti.
sn49.23-34:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant develops and cultivates the four right efforts depending on and grounded on ethics.

sn49.23-34:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro sammappadhāne bhāveti, cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkaroti?

sn49.23-34:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu anuppannānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ anuppādāya chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati …pe…
sn49.23-34:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise. …

sn49.23-34:1.5.pli: uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.23-34:1.5.eng: so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

sn49.23-34:1.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya cattāro sammappadhāne bhāveti, cattāro sammappadhāne bahulīkarotī”ti.
sn49.23-34:1.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant develops and cultivates the four right efforts depending on and grounded on ethics.”

sn49.23-34:2.2.eng: a tree, a pot, and a spike,

sn49.23-34:2.3.eng: the atmosphere, and two on clouds,

sn49.23-34:2.4.eng: a ship, a guest house, and a river.

sn49.35-44:1.3.eng: The search for sensual pleasures, the search for continued existence, and the search for a spiritual path.

sn49.35-44:1.5.pli: Imāsaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṃ esanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā.
sn49.35-44:1.5.eng: The four right efforts should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these three searches.

sn49.35-44:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise. …

sn49.35-44:1.8.pli: uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.35-44:1.8.eng: so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

sn49.35-44:1.9.pli: Imāsaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tissannaṃ esanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ime cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
sn49.35-44:1.9.eng: These four right efforts should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these three searches.”

sn49.35-44:2.2.eng: states of existence, three kinds of suffering,

sn49.45-54:1.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

sn49.45-54:1.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

sn49.45-54:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā.
sn49.45-54:1.5.eng: The four right efforts should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

sn49.45-54:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and strives so that bad, unskillful qualities don’t arise. …

sn49.45-54:1.8.pli: uppannānaṃ kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṃ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṃ ārabhati cittaṃ paggaṇhāti padahati.
sn49.45-54:1.8.eng: so that skillful qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.

sn49.45-54:1.9.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya ime cattāro sammappadhānā bhāvetabbā”ti.
sn49.45-54:1.9.eng: These four right efforts should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.”

sn49.45-54:1.10.eng: (Tell in full as in SN 45.171–179, with the above as the final discourse.)

sn49.45-54:2.4.eng: aggregates, and fetters high and low.

sn49.45-54:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the Right Efforts is the fifth section.

sn50.1-12:1.3.eng: The powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.

sn50.1-12:1.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn50.1-12:1.5.eng: The Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn50.1-12:1.6.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañca balāni bhāvento pañca balāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn50.1-12:1.6.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the five powers slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn50.1-12:1.7.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañca balāni bhāvento pañca balāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn50.1-12:1.7.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the five powers slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn50.1-12:1.8.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhābalaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ,
sn50.1-12:1.8.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the powers of faith,

sn50.1-12:1.12.pli: paññābalaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn50.1-12:1.12.eng: and wisdom, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn50.1-12:1.13.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañca balāni bhāvento pañca balāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn50.1-12:1.13.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the five powers slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn50.1-12:2.1.eng: Six on slanting to the east,

sn50.1-12:2.2.eng: and six on slanting to the ocean;

sn50.1-12:2.4.eng: and that’s how this chapter is recited.

sn50.13-22:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the chapter on diligence at SN 45.139–148.)

sn50.13-22:2.1.eng: The Realized One, footprint, roof peak,

sn50.23-34:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the chapter on hard work at SN 45.149–160.)

sn50.23-34:2.2.eng: a tree, a pot, and a spike,

sn50.23-34:2.3.eng: the atmosphere, and two on clouds,

sn50.23-34:2.4.eng: a ship, a guest house, and a river.

sn50.35-44:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in the chapter on searches at SN 45.161–170.)

sn50.35-44:2.2.eng: states of existence, three kinds of suffering,

sn50.45-54:1.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

sn50.45-54:1.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

sn50.45-54:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya pañca balāni bhāvetabbāni.
sn50.45-54:1.5.eng: The five powers should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

sn50.45-54:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu, saddhābalaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ,
sn50.45-54:1.7.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the powers of faith,

sn50.45-54:1.11.pli: paññābalaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn50.45-54:1.11.eng: and wisdom, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn50.45-54:1.12.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya imāni pañca balāni bhāvetabbānī”ti.
sn50.45-54:1.12.eng: These five powers should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.”

sn50.45-54:1.13.eng: (Tell in full as in SN 45.171–179, with the above as the final discourse.)

sn50.55-66:0.2.eng: 6. Another Chapter of Abbreviated Texts on the Ganges

sn50.55-66:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn50.55-66:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn50.55-66:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañca balāni bhāvento pañca balāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn50.55-66:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the five powers slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn50.55-66:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañca balāni bhāvento pañca balāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn50.55-66:1.3.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the five powers slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn50.55-66:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu, saddhābalaṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ …
sn50.55-66:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom, which culminate in the removal of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn50.55-66:1.5.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañca balāni bhāvento pañca balāni bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn50.55-66:1.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the five powers slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn50.55-66:1.6.eng: (Tell in full for each of the different rivers as in SN 45.91–102, removal of greed version.)

sn50.55-66:2.1.eng: Six on slanting to the east,

sn50.55-66:2.2.eng: and six on slanting to the ocean;

sn50.55-66:2.4.eng: and that’s how this chapter is recited.

sn50.67-76:0.2.eng: 6. Another Chapter of Abbreviated Texts on the Ganges

sn50.67-76:1.1.pli: On Display: Title of Section Only
sn50.67-76:1.1.eng: (This text consists of the title only. Tell in full as in SN 45.139–148, removal of greed version.)

sn50.77-88:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in SN 45.149–160, removal of greed version.)

sn50.89-98:1.1.eng: (Tell in full as in SN 45.161–170, removal of greed version.)

sn50.89-98:2.2.eng: states of existence, three kinds of suffering,

sn50.99-108:1.3.eng: Desire for rebirth in the realm of luminous form, desire for rebirth in the formless realm, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance.

sn50.99-108:1.4.eng: These are the five higher fetters.

sn50.99-108:1.5.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya pañca balāni bhāvetabbāni.
sn50.99-108:1.5.eng: The five powers should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

sn50.99-108:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddhābalaṃ bhāveti …pe… paññābalaṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ.
sn50.99-108:1.7.eng: A mendicant develops the powers of faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom, which culminate in the removal of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn50.99-108:1.8.pli: Imesaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcannaṃ uddhambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ abhiññāya pariññāya parikkhayāya pahānāya imāni pañca balāni bhāvetabbānī”ti.
sn50.99-108:1.8.eng: These five powers should be developed for the direct knowledge, complete understanding, finishing, and giving up of these five higher fetters.”

sn50.99-108:2.4.eng: aggregates, and fetters high and low.

sn50.99-108:2.5.eng: The Linked Discourses on the Powers is the sixth section.

sn51.1:1.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā apārā pāraṃ gamanāya saṃvattanti.
sn51.1:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when these four bases of psychic power are developed and cultivated they lead to going from the near shore to the far shore.

sn51.1:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ bhāveti,
sn51.1:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to enthusiasm, and active effort.

sn51.1:1.4.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to energy, and active effort.

sn51.1:1.5.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to mental development, and active effort.

sn51.1:1.6.eng: They develop the basis of psychic power that has immersion due to inquiry, and active effort.

sn51.1:1.7.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro iddhipādā bhāvitā bahulīkatā apārā pāraṃ gamanāya saṃvattantī”ti.
sn51.1:1.7.eng: When these four bases of psychic power are developed and cultivated they lead to going from the near shore to the far shore.”
